results.title: Abakanowicz in Australia
results.creator_credit: Christopher McGill, Malcolm Otton, Crafts Council of Australia and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Polish artist Magdalena Abakanowicz prepares for an exhibition of her work in Australia. We see her exhibits of large rope, hessian and string three-dimensional forms. She comments upon her intended purpose in working with such materials. Narrated by Margaret Throsby.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher McGill, Malcolm Otton, Crafts Council of Australia and Film Australia

results.title: Fifty Years of Service
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description: The first fifty years of the State Electricity Commission is presented by means of archival film detailing highlights of the development of the power authority for Victoria - from 1919 to the completion of the giant Hazelwood power complex.

results.title: What Do We Want?
results.creator_credit: Carlo Zeccola, Molly O'Connor, Philippa Campey, Film Camp and Reko Rennie
results.credit_line:
2022
Reko Rennie, Kamilaroi
Three-channel video
Commissioned by ACMI and Artbank
results.brief_description: What Do We Want draws on 1970s Blaxploitation films and Rennie’s own martial arts practice to explore political, environmental and social questions through an Aboriginal Australian lens.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Carlo Zeccola, Molly O’Connor, Philippa Campey, Film Camp and Reko Rennie
results.description:
An army of First Nations warriors come out to play in this work by Kamilaroi artist Reko Rennie.

An all-Indigenous crew of martial arts students train together in their dojo; learning teachings of discipline, self-defense and teamwork. When the Sensei cries, “What do we want?” the students respond, “Restitution! Land back! Equality! No more cops killing our mob!”, vocalising demands of environmental, political and social concern, and reflecting the broad diversity within contemporary Indigenous urban society.

Rennie was taught martial arts by his father while growing up in Melbourne’s inner West. What Do We Want? marries his 25-year history of martial arts and his arts practice, while expanding Rennie’s evolving moving image repertoire into the realm of performance.

What Do We Want? takes influence from martial arts films including Blaxploitation films of the 1970s and 80s; utilising the medium to make a statement about authenticity, respect, bravery and collective power. The students in What Do We Want? become a force to be reckoned with.

The work loudly and proudly conveys the diversity of First Nations peoples, and the ongoing fight for justice that unifies them, raising urgent questions that require action and response.

Acknowledgements

Director: Reko Rennie

Produced by Film Camp, Philippa Campey, Molly O’Connor

Original composition by A.B. Original

results.title: Allures
results.brief_description: Abstract animation by Jordan Belson. Intended to express “the subliminal rhythms of the inner cosmos”, this experimental film portrays an hallucinogenic voyage into outer space. It consists of sequences featuring interplay of dots, lines, planes, intricate kaleidoscopic designs, circles, grids, rhythms, textures, intensities and variations of focus. The images themselves often suggest the infinity of outer space or of subatomic particles, the snappy impersonality of computers or the undulation of romantic coloured clouds, provide filmed contrasts and tensions complemented by a musical soundtrack which itself acts as a counterpoint.
results.description: Abstract animation by Jordan Belson. Intended to express “the subliminal rhythms of the inner cosmos”, this experimental film portrays an hallucinogenic voyage into outer space. results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Papua New Guinea and United States, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film shows a trip to the USA and Australia. It includes footage of the World Trade Centre twin towers and the Statue of Liberty in NYC, Disneyland, Pearl Harbour in Hawaii, Puffing Billy in Melbourne, views of Sydney Harbour, and a snippet back in New Guinea.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:15:00 group of friends of filmmaker gather at a pier
00:02:00:00 view of Twin Towers and the Statue of Liberty from a ferry
00:05:00:00 Red Rocks Amphitheatre in Colorado
00:11:28:00 a visit to Disneyland and a zoo
00:15:53:00 a visit to Pearl Harbour, USS Arizona Memorial in Honolulu, Hawaii, with views from a ferry and of local resort
00:18:45:00 friends with a baby in the Dandenong Ranges, featuring Puffing Billy in Emerald
00:19:54:00 views of Sydney Harbour, Opera House, Harbour Bridge from a high level of a hotel
00:20:14:00 long lost children’s playground featuring UFO style fizzy dizzy’s and sides and seesaws
00:20:22:00 back to New Guinea, a celebration or demonstration

results.title: An Olive Grove in Laharum
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: Toscana Olive Plantation and Laharum Grove, in western Victoria, both operate from the same original plantation of olives, working together to ensure the freshness, quality and flavour of their oil. While they acknowledge Laharum is a peaceful place to live, the workers at these olive farms are hectic, determined to produce some of the best quality olive oil in Victoria.
